channel.title: Comments on: Backbone.js: Object Literals, Views Events, jQuery, and `el`

item.title: By: Janne
item.dc:creator: Janne
item.description:
You. Are. My. Hero! :) I'm just a noob practicing backbone and have been struggling with this exact problem for the past hour. This was the best explanation ever and with it I got it fixed.
Thank you Derick!
item.content:encoded:
You. Are. My. Hero! :) I’m just a noob practicing backbone and have been struggling with this exact problem for the past hour. This was the best explanation ever and with it I got it fixed.

Thank you Derick!

item.title: By: Stanislas Marion
item.dc:creator: Stanislas Marion
item.description: > Object literals in JavaScript are also known by a number of other names: hashes, associative arrays, key/value sets, JSON,I really like your articles, but this put me off. It is simply not true that an object is a hash and saying that is very misleading. See http://www.devthought.com/2012/01/18/an-object-is-not-a-hash/
item.content:encoded: > Object literals in JavaScript are also known by a number of other names: hashes, associative arrays, key/value sets, JSON,I really like your articles, but this put me off. It is simply not true that an object is a hash and saying that is very misleading. See http://www.devthought.com/2012/01/18/an-object-is-not-a-hash/

item.title: By: Don
item.dc:creator: Don
item.description: Oops. She told me it worked using the class selector, but I guess she didn't understand. Mea culpa, typo
item.content:encoded: Oops. She told me it worked using the class selector, but I guess she didn’t understand. Mea culpa, typo

item.title: By: Don Mitchell
item.dc:creator: Don Mitchell
item.description: We can't get the id based selector to work ("click #someButton" in your example). When we replace it w/ a class-based selector ("click .someButtonClass"), it works. This seems fairly fundamental but is mystifying us [next step, look at the source code.]
item.content:encoded: We can’t get the id based selector to work (“click #someButton” in your example). When we replace it w/ a class-based selector (“click .someButtonClass”), it works. This seems fairly fundamental but is mystifying us [next step, look at the source code.]

item.title: By: Peter Rust
item.dc:creator: Peter Rust
item.description: orlybriceno: off the top of my head, I don't know why the events aren't being triggered, but here is a good blog post by derick that covers a common problem with events not being triggered: http://lostechies.com/derickbailey/2011/11/09/backbone-js-object-literals-views-events-jquery-and-el/
item.content:encoded:
orlybriceno: off the top of my head, I don’t know why the events aren’t being triggered, but here is a good blog post by derick that covers a common problem with events not being triggered: 
http://lostechies.com/derickbailey/2011/11/09/backbone-js-object-literals-views-events-jquery-and-el/

item.title: By: Anonymous
item.dc:creator: Anonymous
item.description: Hey there, thanks for the explanation. I want to ask you something would this work for backbone 0.5.3? that's the version we're using, and I'm specifying both tagName and className, the elements are being created and rendered correctly (I do an alert with this.el in the render method and see the markup is as I indicated), and as you said I have a single element view that renders itself and a 'directory' view that call the single one and appends the singles to the document ; but still the events are not being triggered, and I don't have any control of the ready section since Im working as a part of a bigger project and the architecture is basically inamovible . Thanks in advance.
item.content:encoded: Hey there, thanks for the explanation. I want to ask you something would this work for backbone 0.5.3? that’s the version we’re using, and I’m specifying both tagName and className, the elements are being created and rendered correctly (I do an alert with this.el in the render method and see the markup is as I indicated), and as you said I have a single element view that renders itself and a ‘directory’ view that call the single one and appends the singles to the document ; but still the events are not being triggered, and I don’t have any control of the ready section since Im working as a part of a bigger project and the architecture is basically inamovible . Thanks in advance.

item.title: By: Paul Garvin
item.dc:creator: Paul Garvin
item.description: Thanks so much for this post. I'm writing my first Backbone app and I've been pulling my hair out wondering why nothing was working.
item.content:encoded: Thanks so much for this post. I’m writing my first Backbone app and I’ve been pulling my hair out wondering why nothing was working.

item.title: By: Phillip Lackey
item.dc:creator: Phillip Lackey
item.description: Ha, I actually just realized what I did - I loaded all my script tags on the bottom of the main html page and your code was the last one so, like you said, I guess that's another way to avoid the problem. :)
item.content:encoded: Ha, I actually just realized what I did – I loaded all my script tags on the bottom of the main html page and your code was the last one so, like you said,  I guess that’s another way to avoid the problem.  :)

item.title: By: Derick Bailey
item.dc:creator: Derick Bailey
item.description:
it's hit or miss, and depends on the size and complexity of the html / js involved. you run the risk of the DOM not being available when the JS is evaluated. if you put that JS at the bottom of the HTML, you're less likely to have a problem, but it's still possible.
i'd rather not have that risk. :)
item.content:encoded:
it’s hit or miss, and depends on the size and complexity of the html / js involved. you run the risk of the DOM not being available when the JS is evaluated. if you put that JS at the  bottom of the HTML, you’re less likely to have a problem, but it’s still possible. 

i’d rather not have that risk. :)

item.title: By: Phillip Lackey
item.dc:creator: Phillip Lackey
item.description: Great article! But the first batch of code that isn't supposed to work actually works (at least for me). Even in IE.
item.content:encoded: Great article!  But the first batch of code that isn’t supposed to work  actually works (at least for me).  Even in IE.
